snippet: The business of Charleston is tourism. Even some African-Americans here said there was no reason to suspend that business, even after one of the worst racist attacks in recent American history.
abstract: City of Charleston, SC, is making effort to move on with daily life in wake of killings at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, with many expressing desire to return to familiar patterns even though deeply stirred by tragedy.

byline.original: By JOHN ELIGON and RICHARD FAUSSET
byline.contributor: Nikita Stewart and Alan Blinder contributed reporting from Charleston.

lead_paragraph: The business of Charleston is tourism. Even some African-Americans here said there was no reason to suspend that business, even after one of the worst racist attacks in recent American history.

headline.main: After Killings, a Southern Tourist Destination Remains Calm, and Open
headline.print_headline: Moving On, a Southern Tourist Destination Exhibits Life After Death

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church (Charleston, SC)
